data.title: Add POV support to Android controller backend
data.body:
POV was reported as axes or buttons (depending on the controller) and not properly translated into `PovDirection`

Tested on Galaxy S6, Asus TF700, Nexus Player and Ouya with the following controllers:

- MOGA Pro Power
- Wireless Bluetooth Gamepad w/ Keyboard
- Nexus Player Gamepad
- Ouya Controller
- Logitech F510
- Thrustmaster Dual Trigger 3-in-1
- Thrustmaster T-Flight Stick X

data.title: [feature request] support for separated attributes in vertex buffers
data.body:
Hello, libgdx only support interleaved vertex buffers, this is very nice for static geometry because it may be a good cache optimization (https://www.khronos.org/opengl/wiki/Vertex_Specification_Best_Practices#Interleaving), but although it may be an optimization for static geometry, for dynamic geometry changed by cpu each frame this doesn't help much, because the cache optimization you may gain in the gpu is lost in the cpu side, for example: for a morph animation implementation #2633,  I would prefer to have the attributes separated in the vertex buffer, because I am only modifying position and normals, and it is more cache friendly (I guess) if the data I will modify is close in memory (shape key blending is usually just, v[i] = v[i]+ (shape_factor)*ov[i], n[i] = n[i]+ (shape_factor)*on[i] ) .

but things may be even better, I may have only the attributes I will update separated and the static ones interleaved, well , I don't know how good would be that, but I guess in that way I may have the best of the two approaches, interleaved and separated.

only need to provide the capability of defining offsets and strides of the attributes, right know those are calculated by libgdx.

data.title: Not online Javadoc for LWJGL3
data.body: Now the new project uses LWJGL3 instead of LWJGL as desktop backend by default, but there is still no related API doc online. For example [here](http://libgdx.badlogicgames.com/nightlies/docs/api/) isn't `Lwjgl3Application`, only `LwjglApplication`.

data.title: Convenience Constructor Methods HorizontalGroup and VerticalGroup
data.body: Same convenience constructor methods already exist for Stack.java so it would be nice (and consistent) to have them also in HorizontalGroup and VerticalGroup

data.title: Stage: allow to access/read debugAll Variable
data.body:
its already allowed to change the debugAll variable in Stage.class, why not allow to access/read it as well ?
(its really inconvenient to access it in other ways)

data.title: Invalidating addActorBefore()/addActorAfter() with Table as they do not work (Fixes #4602)
data.body:
I did the suggestion 2. (throw an exception) as suggested in the bottom of Issue #4602

I added documentation to the methods and quoted the documentation [here](https://github.com/libgdx/libgdx/wiki/Table#inserting-cells) which explains that these are not supported and suggests an alternative way to accomplish the desired result.

data.title: TextButton pressedOffsetY not working as expected
animation.getKeyFrames().length throws Casting Exception
data.body:
#### Issue details
Getting the length of the key frame array of an animation causes a Casting Exception.


#### Reproduction steps/code
```java
Array<TextureAtlas.AtlasRegion> regions = textureAtlas.findRegions("test");
Animation<TextureAtlas.AtlasRegion> animation = new Animation<>(.1f, regions, PlayMode.LOOP);
int i = animation.getKeyFrames().length;
```

#### Version of LibGDX and/or relevant dependencies
1.9.6

#### Stacktrace
Error Message: 
```java
Exception in thread "LWJGL Application" java.lang.ClassCastException: [Ljava.lang.Object; cannot be cast to [Lcom.badlogic.gdx.graphics.g2d.TextureAtlas$AtlasRegion;
```

#### Please select the affected platforms
- probably all

data.title: improve OpenALMusic getPosition accuracy fix #4268
data.body:
This is a first shot, maybe more tests would be necessary.

As @riqueaalves explained, renderedSeconds variable is reset too early when looping. My fix stores futur  renderedSeconds values for queued buffers. This should fix position value when last buffer is being loaded and not played yet.

Suggestions welcome!

data.title: Querying Touchscreen Support
data.body:
#### Issue details
I would like to request the ability to query whether or not a touchscreen is available on a given device. Currently we have `Input.Peripheral.MultitouchScreen`, however this is only a subset of touchscreens (touchscreens where multitouch is supported).

My use case is that I'm trying to develop a UI framework, and I need to distinguish between the cases where a touchscreen is available or not, which affects how focus works. In most cases, querying `Input.Peripheral.MultitouchScreen` should be sufficient, however it does not cover all cases. Android provides the ability to query this [distinction](https://developer.android.com/reference/android/content/pm/PackageManager.html#FEATURE_TOUCHSCREEN).

#### Reproduction steps/code
n/a

#### Version of LibGDX and/or relevant dependencies
all

#### Stacktrace
n/a

#### Please select the affected platforms
- [x] Android
- [x] iOS (robovm)
- [x] iOS (MOE)
- [x] HTML/GWT
- [x] Windows
- [x] Linux
- [x] MacOS

data.title: Problem Adding .AARS Dependency
data.body:
#### Issue details
I want to use CMUSphinx in conjunction with libgdx to add voice recognition to the game. In order to use the CMUSphinx library, I need to create a new .aars module in the project. However, when I tried to compile the module in the core build.gradle as a dependency, I got the following error from android/build.gradle:

*****
Module 'ZombieBird:core:1.0' depends on one or more Android libraries but is a jar.
*****

I have tried to compile the module within the android build.gradle and it works fine, I could use methods  etc. in CMUSphinx library in the android module. However, I still can't use them in the core module.

#### Reproduction steps/code
1. Create a libgdx project
2. Create (import) new .AARS module with name 'aars'
3. Compile the .AARS module in core build.gradle with the following code:

    dependencies {
        compile project(':aars')
    }

#### Version of LibGDX and/or relevant dependencies
1.9.5

#### Stacktrace
N/A

#### Please select the affected platforms
- [X ] Android
- [ ] iOS (robovm)
- [ ] iOS (MOE)
- [ ] HTML/GWT
- [ ] Windows
- [ ] Linux
- [ ] MacOS


Thank you in advance for your help.

-Justinus

data.title: Stage ignores mouseMove and touchDown events when moving mouse along upper bound
data.body:
#### Issue details
In GWT fullscreen mode Stage ignores mouseMove and touchDown events when moving mouse along upper bound.

#### Reproduction steps/code
When moving mouse along Stage's upper bound then the following is true:
`Gdx.graphics.getHeight() - screenY == viewport.getScreenY() + viewport.getScreenHeight()`

The methods Stage#mouseMoved and Stage#touchDown both contain the following check:
```
if (Gdx.graphics.getHeight() - screenY < viewport.getScreenY()
	|| Gdx.graphics.getHeight() - screenY >= viewport.getScreenY() + viewport.getScreenHeight()) return false;
```
which ignores the events when moving mouse along upper bound.
This check in both places should be changed to:
```
if (Gdx.graphics.getHeight() - screenY < viewport.getScreenY()
	|| Gdx.graphics.getHeight() - screenY > viewport.getScreenY() + viewport.getScreenHeight()) return false;
```

#### Version of LibGDX and/or relevant dependencies
all

#### Stacktrace
n/a

#### Please select the affected platforms
- [ ] Android
- [ ] iOS (robovm)
- [ ] iOS (MOE)
- [X] HTML/GWT
- [ ] Windows
- [ ] Linux
- [ ] MacOS

data.title: Native library libgdx.so potentially loaded two times on Android
data.body:
#### Issue details
I have noticed that the native library libgdx.so might be loaded twice on Android:

  * first time using GdxNativesLoader (used in AndroidApplication)
  * second time in AndroidGL20 via System.loadLibrary

This might be an artefact of the time when the AndroidGL20 class had its own native library.
From my understanding it should not be needed anymore to call System.loadLibrary explicitly in the AndroidGL20 class.

In general this should not make problems, but when using some obfuscators (e.g. DexGuard) it would be easier if the native library is only loaded via one mechanism, i.e. GdxNativesLoader -> SharedLibraryLoader.

#### Version of LibGDX and/or relevant dependencies
in master (currently 1.9.7-SNAPSHOT?)

#### Please select the affected platforms
- [X] Android

data.title: Javadocs on Input interface for accelerometer are wrong
GestureDetector is leaky.
data.body:
#### Issue details
GestureDetector instances are not collected by GC

#### Reproduction steps/code
2 activities, one creates another with a child activity instantiating gdx.Game where GestureDetector also instantiated. Close the child activity and return to the parent after triggering some gestures. Repeat from creating another child activity. 
From the .hprof files you can see that GestureDetector instances are never collected with a Timer (longPressTask) being the reason. It's never disposed.
 I made a copy of GestureDetector in my project and removed longPressTask since I don't use it, after that GC works as expected.

#### Version of LibGDX and/or relevant dependencies
1.9.6

#### Memory snapshot 

![Dump screenshot](http://i.imgur.com/3Yl3L5B.jpg)


#### Tested platform
- Android 6.0.0

data.title: Touch handling frequency on iOS sometimes 30Hz
added getParticles protected method
data.body: This make it possible for subclass to access `particles` array without using reflection.

data.title: Is it possible to load a list of AndroidApplication view into RecyclerView?
data.body:
From my understanding, in order to display a 3D view, the app need to extends from AndroidApplication. 
In this class, there is a method to initialize view:
`View view = initializeForView(new MyGdxGame(), config);`
Looking at source code of AndroidApplication, I saw a lot of callbacks to deal with Android activity life cycle and a lot of objects like `input`, `files`, `net`, `audio`. So I'm wondering is it reasonable to display these views inside a RecyclerView with adapter model? My goal is not to create a game but rather an app that can display 3D model with transformation and animation.   
Any feedback would be greatly appreciated.

data.title: Sprite.setTextureFit() added.
data.body: Most 24fps animations consist of too many frames and they can't fit in a 4096x4096 sprite sheet. In that case, every frame has to reside in a separate file. setTextureFit (Texture tex) resizes the sprite when a texture with different dimensions from the current one is set. I've chosen that name because it will pop up on the auto-completion menu when someone decides to call setTexture().

data.title: Nortorn anti-vrius recognizing 'gdx-box2d64.dll' as 'unsafe'
data.body:
Hi,

I am running into an issue where Norton Internet Security quarentines the 'gdx-box2d64.dll' when I compile the project. Here is my software and version information:

```
gdxVersion = '1.9.6'
        roboVMVersion = '2.3.0'
        box2DLightsVersion = '1.4'
        ashleyVersion = '1.7.0'
        aiVersion = '1.8.0'
```

Norton version '22,9.0.71'

I whitelisted the directory and moved on. I just wanted to let you know this is happening.

-Andrew

data.title: gdx-facebook version set to 1.3.0
data.body: Set gdx-facebook extension version to 1.3.0

data.title: Add map() function to MathUtils
data.body:
Hey! First, I love `libGDX`. Amazing work :)

There's a function which I've been missing and I find *really* useful, `map()`. It takes an input value and two ranges, start range and end range. It then maps the value from the start to the end range. Pretty useful. I ported it from [Processing](https://github.com/processing/processing/blob/db4f1449e4097e08683a276c64db392f906362b4/core/src/processing/core/PApplet.java#L4369-L4373) because I would love to see it integrated into `libGDX` too.

There is another implementation for [JavaScript](http://stackoverflow.com/a/23202637/4759433), but I took the one from the Processing team (the algorithm to calculate the mapped value is not mine, but it's not something private anyway since it's also available for JavaScript in a different way etc.)
